modules.description: This module provides functions for generating predefined color palettes tied to specific artists, cultural references, or thematic identifiers, operating on structured color lists. It enables mapping distinct names or themes to curated color sets, supporting use cases like design projects requiring historical art styles or thematic visual consistency. The functionality emphasizes patterned naming conventions and contextual associations to streamline color selection for creative or analytical purposes.

Provides color lists representing specific natural scenes and elements, including seasonal transitions, landscapes, and wildlife. Works with lists of color values to model visual themes found in Pacific Northwest environments. Used to generate consistent color schemes for thematic visual projects or data visualization applications.

Provides a set of predefined color palettes named after Wes Anderson films, each returning a list of color values. Works with lists of color representations, typically in RGB or hex format. Used to quickly apply consistent visual themes in graphic design or application interfaces inspired by specific film aesthetics.

Provides pre-defined color lists for specific design themes, each representing a distinct palette for visual projects. Works with lists of color values, typically used in graphic design or data visualization contexts. Used to quickly apply consistent color schemes to applications or layouts.

Provides functions for blending and comparing color values using RGB and HSL representations. Includes operations for converting between color models, adjusting brightness, and calculating color similarity. Used in graphic rendering pipelines to optimize visual consistency and contrast.

combines structured color palettes with thematic and environmental associations, offering named color lists for artistic, natural, and design contexts. It includes artist-specific, film-inspired, and landscape-based color sets, all represented as lists of RGB or hex values. Users can generate consistent visual themes for design projects, data visualization, or interface styling. Examples include applying a Wes Anderson film palette, simulating Pacific Northwest landscapes, or selecting historical art-inspired colors.
